column32: Marc-Andre Beaucher, 2022, pers. comm.
column35: Marc-Andre Beaucher, Head of Conservation Programs at Creston Valley WMA detailed some of the threats to nesting grebes in the CVWMA in general.  Some things unknown are the impacts of water levels and fish populations since there are a lot of exotic fish in the valley.  See Creston Valley Wildlife Management Area (2023) entry for the grebe data

column32: Creston Valley Wildlife Management Area. 2023. Unpublished datta.
column35: Database forwarded from Marc-Andre Beaucher, Head of Conservation Programs, Creston Valley Wildlife Management Area (CVWMA) includes Western grebe survey data from 1968 to 2022 of Duck Lake, Kootenay Lake, Leach Lake and CVWMA in general.  Surveys from 1968 through 2003 are limited in survey data and are once or twice during the breeding season.  Surveys from 2004 through 2022 have more details and are more frequent throughout the breeding season, ranging from once to weekly or almost regularly depending on the year.  Some surveys extended beyond the breeding range so data culled for this inventory is restricted to approximately mid-May through August.   Survey comments often stated that nests and chicks were not mentioned unless there were count numbers for those.  If surveys were conducted mid to late breeding season, I assumed nests and chicks were surveyed for but not found if those columns were zero.  Conversely, zero for an adult count number at a lake did not necessarily signify zero adults were found.  Refer to time surveyed per lake in a given year to see if that lake was surveyed at all, or in the survey dates of that year.  Maximum count numbers for that breeding season for that lake was used for this summary.

column32: Forbes, L. S. 1988. Western grebe nesting in British Columbia. The Murrelet. 28-33
column35: Forbes surveyed for grebes and nests May through August 1981 to 1983 but also sourced historical data from Fyle and Teeple unpubl. ms., Rodgers 1973, and British Columbia Nest Records Scheme for Table 1.  He entered colony once in 1981 and twice each 1982 and 1983.  In 1982, 0.79 productivity considered normal levels.  In 1983, first record of Clark's grebe breeding in B.C.  Eggs were collected and tested for some contaminants in 1982 and deemed to not be a problem.

column32: Forbes, L. S. 1985. Wilson Bull., 97(1), 1985, pp. 122-123
column35: Forbes observed three incidents of extra-pair feeding of young while observing 75 pairs in 1983.

column32: Ydenberg, R. C. and Forbes, L. S. 1988. Diving and foraging in the Western Grebe. - Ornis Scand. 19: 129-133.
column35: This is a study on diving and foraging of Western grebes at this lake.  There were 230 observable individuals on the lake, of which 180 (90 pairs) were breeding on the lake and observed foraging for their broods.  No other details or data besides dive time.

column35: Species profile on Clark's grebes at their two known breeding locations in B.C.  Very infrequent breeder at Duck Lake (2 breeding records) and rare summer visitor.  Anecdotal accounts per year show very few numbers and includes a hybrid chick in 1983.  In 2000, one Clark's chick was being fed by red-necked grebe pair.

column32: Blood, D. A., and F. Backhouse. 1999. Western grebe, low breeding numbers and threats to their nesting colonies put these birds at risk. Wildlife at risk in British Columbia. Ministry of Environment, Lands and Parks. Victoria, British Columbia, Canada.
column35: One of 3 existing colonies as of publication year.  At CVWMA, 55 pairs breeding there in "recent years" (assuming the 1990s based on publication year).  Began nesting there in the 1960s.

column30: 74 aerial surveys from 1988-1990. Other years, no info.
column33: Burger, A. E. 1997. Status of the Western Grebe in British Columbia. Wildlife Working Report WR-87, Wildlife Branch, Ministry of the Environment, Lands and Parks, Victoria, British Columbia, Canada.
column35: Grebes started to nest there in the 1960s after diking, water level regulation, and emergent vegetation enhancement  (Forbes 1984, Butler et al. 1986).  Combined Table 2 (only 1 year of data - 1981) and narrative with incomplete survey data for this entry.  Sources are BCNRS (B. C. Nest Record Scheme of the Royal B. C. Museum), Rodgers (1973), Forbes (1984), CVWMA unpubl. reports, and unpubl. data from S. Boyd, A.E. Burger, S. Cannings, and B. Stushnoff.  96% of the grebes are on Duck Lake while 2 % are on Leach Lake, 1% on Kootenay Lake, and 1% on other smaller lakes of the CVWMA complex.  Infestation of milfoil weed limits open water for foraging.  Considered the most protected nesting sites in B.C. due to the Creston Valley Wildlife Act.  Western grebe research was high priority for the CVWMA but the federal government withdrew funding and no work continued on the grebes since 1990.  The  cause(s) of low breeding success of grebes remains unknown.

column23: Mostly Western.  1 Clark's was seen in 2008 and 2018.
column32: Creston Valley Wildlife Management Area. 2023. Unpublished datta.
column35: Database forwarded from Marc-Andre Beaucher, Head of Conservation Programs, Creston Valley Wildlife Management Area (CVWMA) includes Western grebe survey data from 1968 to 2022 of Duck Lake, Kootenay Lake, Leach Lake and CVWMA in general.  Surveys from 1968 through 2003 are limited in survey data and are once or twice during the breeding season.  Surveys from 2004 through 2022 have more details and are more frequent throughout the breeding season, ranging from once to weekly or almost regularly depending on the year.  Some surveys extended beyond the breeding range so data culled for this inventory is restricted to approximately mid-May through August.   Survey comments often stated that nests and chicks were not mentioned unless there were count numbers for those.  If surveys were conducted mid to late breeding season, I assumed nests and chicks were surveyed for but not found if those columns were zero.  Conversely, zero for an adult count number at a lake did not necessarily signify zero adults were found.  Refer to time surveyed per lake in a given year to see if that lake was surveyed at all, or in the survey dates of that year.  Maximum count numbers for that breeding season for that lake was used for this summary.

column32: Creston Valley Wildlife Management Area. 2023. Unpublished datta.

Conversely, zero for an adult count number at a lake did not necessarily signify zero adults were found.  Refer to time surveyed per lake in a given year to see if that lake was surveyed at all, or in the survey dates of that year.  Maximum count numbers for that breeding season for that lake was used for this summary.  In 2004, though chick count was zero, some could be mixed in with the adult count but that is uncertain.  Also, the one chick in 2012 was on Kootenay River as part of Kootenay Lake's entry.

column32: Woods, John. 2022. Unpublished data. Personal communications.
column35: Data from datasheets of yearly counts in Salmon Arm Bay conducted by local biologist Dianne Wittner, forwarded by John Woods.  Nests counts were not conducted but I included a historical observation John included by David Stirling in 1962 of 9 nests.  The datasheets were from 2016 to 2022 with adult and chick counts in the months of June, July, and/or August.  There may have been more than one observer as sometimes chicks and juveniles were combined with the adult counts and other times chick counts were seperate.  Count numbers were within a similar range for each year, varying between the months, so I estimated general ranges as maximums and minimums to compile this record.

Breeding first recorded in 1962 (Stirling 1962) though with low success in the 1960s (Buffan 1964, Stirling 1964), then stabilizing with 40 to 50 in the 1970s and 1980s.  Grebes counted at the colony increased in the 1990s. column32: Campbell, W.R., F.J.E. Hillary and L.M. Van Damme. 2009. Clark's Grebe. Wildlife Data Centre -featured species. Wildlife Afield. Vol. 6 (1). 105 pp.
column35: Species profile on Clark's grebes at their two known breeding locations in B.C.  There are very few Clark's grebes counted over the breeding season and possibly only one to three pairs breed within the Western grebe colony and include some mixed pairs (paired with Western grebes).  Average over 22 year span is 1.8 Clark's grebes which may be an underestimate.  The year by year anecdotes are confusing and numbers culled from each year are marked as (C) for Clark's, (H) for hybrid, and (W) for Western, if included.  This document is about Clark's grebes but Western grebe counts were included if mentioned though they might not always been accounted for or were generalized as present or as a colony.   Many mentions of hybrid pairs.  Clark's/Western/hybrid ratios were based on 2008 description of numbers.

On the second visit in June 1963 (Frank Buffam and Doug and Anne Dow), only 6 nests remained out of 26, the other 20 had disappeared.  He notes the colony's location about a mile from a marina and the potential for disturbance but also notes that it is out of the way for boaters.

column32: Campbell, R. W., Dawe, N. K., McTaggart-Cowan, I., Cooper, J., Kaiser, G. W., McNall, M., & Campbell, R. W. C. W. S. (1992). Nonpasserines : Introduction, loons through waterfowl. UBC Press.

Campbell et al. (1992) sources are from British Columbia Nest Records Scheme.  There was confirmation of nesting in 1987 but no count.  I didn't include that year in this entry because no numbers were associated with that year.  Disturbance and unstable water levels attributed to the lack of nesting grebes.

column32: Weber, W. C., and J. Ireland. 1992. Tidewater breeding records of the Western Grebe near Vancouver, British Columbia. Western Birds 23:33-34.
column35: 1986 observations by Ireland, September 1988 observations by Weber and October 1988 observations by Brian G. Self and D. Michael Price, all off of Reifel Migratory Bird Sanctuary at the mouth of the Fraser River.  These two breeding records may be the first records for western grebe breeding on the B.C. coast on tidewater anywhere.  At the mouth of the Fraser River, the marshes have brackish water and have a mean tidal range of 3.1 m to 4.8 m at the extreme, making it a challenge to nest there.  The chicks were observed late in the season, suggesting they may have hatched from renesting efforts after an unsuccessful nesting attempt.  They could have also hatched from nests further up the Fraser River but that is unlikely.  Most summers, there are 50 to 100 grebes in the summer near Westham Island but no evidence of breeding before 1986.

column33:
Burger, A. E. 1997. Status of the Western Grebe in British Columbia. Wildlife Working
Report WR-87, Wildlife Branch, Ministry of the Environment, Lands and Parks, Victoria, British
Columbia, Canada.
column35: There was rare breeding on this lake with two years of a single brood of 2 chicks each year (Weber and Ireland 1992).  Tidal flux impacts the Fraser River delta marshes where they may have nested, possibly the first tidewater breeding record for Western grebes.  Most summers (years not given), 30 to 100 grebes are present but no observed breeding prior to 1986 nor since 1988 (J. Ireland, pers. comm.).

The 1935 observation is of about 35 pairs and the 1941 observation is of 50 pairs (both multiplied by 2 for total estimate of adults).  The 1939 observation of 25 nests was made by Leo John.

column33:
Burger, A. E. 1997. Status of the Western Grebe in British Columbia. Wildlife Working
Report WR-87, Wildlife Branch, Ministry of the Environment, Lands and Parks, Victoria, British

column35: Considered a lake with historically regular breeding in the 1930s and 1940s, but now extirpated.  Last recorded breeding was in 1964 though chicks were sighted in 1974. There are still summer visitors but numbers declined since the 1940s and were usually less than 10 birds during the breeding season in the 1980s.  No nest surveys since the 1970s were conducted.  Combined Table 2 and Table 4 (June through August numbers only, not including increases in August due to possible migration stopover) data with some minor discrepencies and incomplete survey data.  Survey years from 1935 to 1995 with some skipped years and no numbers for adults during breeding season in 1990, 1992, and 1995.  Unclear if surveys were conducted during the breeding season those years or zero counts were left blank.  Sources are BCNRS (B. C. Nest Record Scheme of the Royal B. C. Museum), SRC (Sight Record Cards of the Royal B. C. Museum, and SINC (Scout Island Nature Centre).

column35: MAYBE THIS SHOULD NOT BE INCLUDED BECAUSE NON-BREEDING ADULTS (low #).  From Table A.1, maximum counts of Western grebes (which may include non-breeding adults) at breeding lakes in B.C. from June to August (Burger 1997, Anderson et al. 2011).  Stated as 20 year chunks: 1970 - 1990 and 1991 - 2011 without breaking those down into years or other details.  The 28 in 1970 - 1990 are non-breeding adults with no estimated nor confirmed breeding.  There is no count for 1991 - 2011.  No breeding reported since 1964.  From 1930s to 1964, supported 5 to 35 nests but ceased due to human disturbance and development (Burger 1997).

column35: In an email from John Woods (2023), cites Munro and Cowan (1947) that Western grebes were only nesting at Williams Lake and Swan Lake in B.C. historically, with 50 pairs in 1941 in Williams Lake.  However, by 1962, the colony declined and no longer remained due to speedboats.

column35: This article is on the occurrence of Clark's grebes and hybrids with Western grebes (intermediates) in prairie Canada.  June count by T. Underwood and J. Rasmussen who found only one Clark's grebe (nest?).  R. Bazin, J. Hopkins, L. Beaudoin, and D. Wrubelski found no Clark's grebes (H. den Haan pers. comm.) in their July survey of 8 sites.  Unknown whether both surveys were in the same areas and are comparable within the same year.  Intermediates were not recorded for this lake.

column32: COSEWIC. 2014. COSEWIC assessment and status report on the Western Grebe Aechmophorus occidentalis in Canada. Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada. Ottawa. x + 55 pp. (www.registrelep-sararegistry.gc.ca/default_e.cfm).
column35: From Table A.4, maximum counts of breeding Western grebes from surveys conducted during nesting season from 1970 to 1990 and 1991 to 2011 without breaking those down into years or other details (sourced from Wilson, A. and Smith, P.A. 2013. Distribution and population status of Western Grebes in Canada. Unpublished report for the Canadian Wildlife Service).  The 30 from 1991 to 2011 are non-breeding adults.  Egg predation mainly by Forster's Terns and American Coots (Nuechterlein 1975) but lately that's decreased (La Porte 2012).  Non-native carp also attributed to destroying 41 grebe nests (La Porte 2012).  64 grebes drowned in gillnets (La Porte 2012).  Winterkill of minnows attributed to colony abandonment (Nuechterlein pers. comm. in Allen et al. 2007).  Considered well protected as the Delta Marsh Wildlife Management Area.

column32: La Porte, N., Koper, N., & Leston, L. (2014). Assessing the Breeding Success of the Western Grebe (Aechmophorus occidentalis) after 40 Years of Environmental Changes at Delta Marsh, Manitoba. Waterbirds: The International Journal of Waterbird Biology, 37(1), 30–42. http://www.jstor.org/stable/24640958
column35: Comparison study in 2009 and 2010 compared to 1973 and 1974 (Nuechterlein 1975) grebe survey.  Though adult count numbers remain fairly stable and even increased, 2009 and 2010's reduced breeding success is attributed to wave action.  Other threats, some related to generating or mitigating waves, include spawning common carp, depradation, changes in vegetation structure (nesting habitat quality), and low water levels.  This marsh is connected to Lake Manitoba and was considered a historically high productive area for grebes, with a nest success rate of 84% and productivity rate of 0.88 in 1974 (Nuechterlein 1975).  After Nuechterlein's study, there's been a lack of grebe surveys until 2005 (Underwood and Rasmussen, 2005).  There's been one-day surveys from an airboat in part of Delta Marsh in June 2005, 2006 and 2007 conducted by Ducks Unlimited Canada (DUC) and the Canadian Wildlife Service (CWS).  I did not enter these numbers cited here because those sound like partial surveys.  Counts were 346 nests in 2005 (Underwood and Rasmussen 2005, unpublished data), 307 nests in 2006 (Bazin et al. 2006, unpublished data), and 588 nests in 2007 (Basin et al. 2007, unpublished data).  Nuechterlein named three major factors to nest success for his tudy, wave impacts, water depth, and emergent vegetation stem density.  Since the last 40 years from LaPorte's study, an invasive hybrid cattail (Typha x glauca)  was outcompeting native shoreline vegetation and growing in dense monotypic stands.  Otherwise, nesting was predominantly in bulrush in 1973 and 1974.  Low water levels made these hybrid cattail stands impenetrable to grebes as nesting habitat.  A decrease in submerged vegetation in the open water since the 1970s also reduces the buffer to wave energy.  Water turbidity also increased due to carp presence which can limit visibility for foraging grebes.  Carp barriers between the marsh and Lake Manitoba can also drown grebes moving between the two waterbodies.  Nuechterlein attributed better breeding success in 1974 relative to 1973 to higher water levels in 1974, which increased quality and quantity of nesting habitat.  1973, along with 2010 were considered low water years while 1974 and 2009 were high water years.  In 1973, a low water year, nests were exposed and impacted by high winds, resulting in less nest success than in 1974.  In a low water year at Delta marsh, breeding success was ~50% less than a high water year even if water levels were ~30 cm higher at the start of the nesting season (Nuechterlein 1975).  A sampling of nests for nest success showed that nest success of 84% in 1974 was significantly higher than 49% in 2009 and 43% in 2010.  There were a variety of threats to nests in 2009 and 2010 but the top three were wave impacts, destruction by spawning carp, and abandonment due to low water levels.  The 2009 adult and chick counts include Lake Manitoba because of the channel connection between the two areas.  LaPorte also cites the multi-modality of clutch initiations in 2009 and 2010 to increased rates of nest failures from wave impacts from storms and the renesting that occurs.  Abandonment rates due to researcher disturbance in 2009 and 2010 was greatly reduced by nearly 76% from the 1970s surveys.  LaPorte also states that controlled water drawdowns are also  beneficial to bolster bulrush growth though low water levels negatively impoact grebe nesting.

column32: Nuechterlein, G. L. 1975. Nesting ecology of western grebes on the delta marsh. M.Sc. thesis, Department of Fishery and Wildlife Biology, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado.105 pp.
column35: Nesting success was 46% for 1973 colonies and 84% for 1974 colonies.  In 1973, there was low marsh water levels which limited accessible nesting habitat.  It is hypothesized that this caused grebes to nest in less optimal nesting habitat vulnerable to wind and wave inundation.  Predation was not thought to have a major impact on nest success.  However, colonies near canoe passages were vulnerable to human disturbance and nests were abandoned at a higher rate.

The highest count of 2020 is 82 from eBird (https://ebird.org/canada/checklist/S69534269).  Threat described as changes in water level but doesn't specify if too high or too low.

column32: COSEWIC. 2014. COSEWIC assessment and status report on the Western Grebe Aechmophorus occidentalis in Canada. Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada. Ottawa. x + 55 pp. (www.registrelep-sararegistry.gc.ca/default_e.cfm).
column35: Estimate of breeding Western grebe population in Manitoba using data from 2002 to 2012.  Adults were either directly counted or the number of active nests were doubled (Beyersbergen and Calvert 2008; Wollis and Stratmoen 2010) and counts of adults on lakes without breeding observed were included (Wilson and Smith 2013).  In Manitoba, only one survey was conducted in most colonies in the past 10 years (Wilson and Smith 2013).   In 1979, an aerial survey of breeding sites in this province gave an estimate of 10270 adults in 11 colonies (Koonz and Rakowski 1985).  Current estimate is 8653 to 11403 adult grebes (Wilson and Smith 2013).  The population in this province considered relatively stable with less yearly fluctuations than Alberta and Saskatchewan (Wilson and Smith 2013).  About 25% of Canada's breeding population is in one colony in Manitoba (not sure which one).

column32: Forsyth, D. J., P. A. Martin, K. D. De Smet and M. E. Riske. (1994b). Organochlorine contaminants and eggshell thinning in grebes from prairie Canada. Environmental Pollution 85:51-58.
column35: Western grebe eggs were collected at Duck Bay (14 eggs total) and Ninette (20 eggs total) in Manitoba in 1986 as part of this study of organochlorine residues in grebe eggs.  All sampled eggs had significant levels of DDE and PCB residues.  DDD was detected in all western grebe egg samples.  They are considered the most piscivorous of the grebes in North America and thus more vulnerable to contaminants.  Western grebe large body mass relative to other grebes also decreases toxicant metabolism.  The DDD, DDE, and PCB levels in the Manitoba lakes were comparable to a larger study in Klamath Basin, California in 1981 (Boellstorff et al. 1985).  Contaminants might be taken up in their wintering and spring grounds.

column33: Somers, C. M., L. M. Heisler, J. L. Doucette, V. A. Kjoss, and R. M. Brigham. 2015. Lake Use by Three Avian Piscivores and Humans: Implications for Angler Perception and Conservation. The Open Ornithology Journal 8:10–21.
column35: This is a study on angler perception of piscivorous birds.  Between 26 to 31 point counts from 2005 to 2007 were conducted at 18 point count stations from the shore of this lake.  Grebes with young were observed in all three years of the surveys, confirming breeding (C. Somers, pers. comm.).  There was a positive correlation between grebes and boat presence.  Count numbers are entered as mean +/- SD from Table 1.  No formal sutveys have been done on this lake so colony characteristics are unknown.

column32: Konter, A. (2009). Occurrence of Clark’s Grebes and their hybrids with Western Grebes in Prairie Canada. Blue Jay 67, 26-33.
column35: This article is on the occurrence of Clark's grebes and hybrids with Western grebes (intermediates) in prairie Canada.  Only 80 of the grebes could be identified, hence more than half are unknown (U).  This study shows that Clark's grebe presence in Canada could be 1% or less of total grebes.

column33: Somers, C. M., L. M. Heisler, J. L. Doucette, V. A. Kjoss, and R. M. Brigham. 2015. Lake Use by Three Avian Piscivores and Humans: Implications for Angler Perception and Conservation. The Open Ornithology Journal 8:10–21.
column35: This is a study on angler perception of piscivorous birds.  Between 26 to 31 point counts from 2005 to 2007 were conducted at 20 point count stations from the shore of this lake.  Grebes with young were observed in all three years of the surveys, confirming breeding.  There was a positive correlation between grebes and boat presence.  Count numbers are entered as mean +/- SD from Table 1.  No formal sutveys have been done on this lake so colony characteristics are unknown.  In 2005 and 2007, a colony of more than 1000 pairs of grebes were established in the wetlands in the south part of this lake area (K. Hecker, pers. comm.).

column32: Nero, Lahrman, and Bard. 1958. Dry land nest site of a Western grebe colony. Auk 75:347-349
column35: Observation of dry-land nests due to dropping water levels.  Not really a survey, but intermittent observations and counts in 1953, 1956 and 1957 but not consistently. column35: Estimate of breeding Western grebe population in Saskatchewan using data from 2002 to 2012.  Adults were either directly counted or the number of active nests were doubled (Beyersbergen and Calvert 2008; Wollis and Stratmoen 2010) and counts of adults on lakes without breeding observed were included (Wilson and Smith 2013).  Provincial estimates are the averages of summing the most recent surveys of all colonies, summing the second most recent surveys (or most recent survey), and summing the average colony abundance of 2002 to 2012 (one to three surveys) (Wilson and Smith 2013).  No trend data available for this province and surveys prior to 2008 were limited for appropriate comparisons with current estimates (Wilson and Smith 2013).

column35: Breeding likely in 1953 but no nest count or other confirmation.  Historic observation.  This and other similar reservoirs in the region nest only when water is high enough to flood the emergent vegetation.  In 1957 to 1959, water levels were favorable for nesting.  In 1960, water levels were below capacity, nesting habitat was not inundated with water, and though grebes were present, no nesting occurred at the reservoirs in the Fort Collins region.  Entered 0 as 1960 nest count.

column32: Donald G. Davis, Western Grebe Colonies in Northern Colorado, The Condor, Volume 63, Issue 3, May 1961, Pages 264–265, https://doi-org.uidaho.idm.oclc.org/10.1093/condor/63.3.264
column35: Historic observation.  This and other similar reservoirs in the region nest only when water is high enough to flood the emergent vegetation.  In 1957 to 1959, water levels were favorable for nesting.  However, in 1957 there was poor nesting success and 1958 nest success was better.  In 1960, water levels were below capacity, nesting habitat was not inundated with water, and no nesting occurred at the reservoirs in the Fort Collins region.  Entered 0 as 1960 nest count.

column35: Conducted as part of Western Colonial Waterbird Survey (WCWS), a breeding survey of 18 species from May to July 2009 to 2011, resulting in this Atlas.  State data, presented in Table 6, reflects maximum value across all surveys and years of WCWS for colonies visited more than once.  Nest counts were used to estimate breeding adult counts when possible as direct adult counts may include non-breeders.

column32: Beason, J., R. Levad, and T. Leukering. 2005. Monitoring Colorado’s Birds: The 2004 field season report. Rocky Mountain Bird Observatory unpub. report. __ pp.
column35: Per authors, active nest count = # nests detected + 0.5*(juveniles detected) (Table 16 and Table 18).  All Western grebe nesting sites in CO known to have been occupied in the last 3 years were censussed, except for Empire Reservoir due to access issues.  22 of 26 historical and potential nesting sites were surveyed and 2 had confirmed breeding in 2004.  Nesting was limited due to low water levels that reduced nesting opportunities.  In the narrative, since the start of surveying in 1998, 27 sites had nesting but most (20) had nesting only once and none for all the years.  These numbers are different from Table 16.  No site had more than 11 nests in a breeding season.  Drought is attributed as a cause to the downward trend.

column32: Beason, J., R. Levad, and T. Leukering. 2005. Monitoring Colorado’s Birds: The 2004 field season report. Rocky Mountain Bird Observatory unpub. report. __ pp.
column35: Per authors, active nest count = # nests detected + 0.5*(juveniles detected) (Table 16 and Table 19).  All Clark's grebe nesting sites in CO known to have been occupied in the last 5 years were censussed, except for Empire Reservoir due to access issues.  29 of 35 historical and potential nesting sites were surveyed and 2 had confirmed breeding in 2004.  Nesting was limited due to low water levels that reduced nesting opportunities.  Since the start of surveying in 1998, 15 sites had nesting but most (10) had nesting only once and none for all the years.  In 2004, nesting was confirmed at only 2 sites.  Table 16 shows 5 Clark's grebe nests counted in 2004 but Table 19 shows 3 nests, I entered 5.  Drought is attributed as a cause to the downward trend.

column32: Leukering, Tony; Beason, Jason; Levad, Rich. 2004. Monitoring Colorado's birds: the 2003 field season report. In cooperation with Rocky Mountain Bird Observatory
column35: Per authors, active nest count = # nests detected + 0.5*(juveniles detected) (Table 14 and Table 19).  All Western grebe nesting sites in CO known to have been occupied in the last 3 years were censussed, except for Empire Reservoir due to access issues.  43 of 60 historical and potential nesting sites were surveyed and 5 had confirmed breeding in 2003.  Nesting was limited due to low water levels that reduced nesting opportunities.  In the narrative, since the start of surveying in 1998, 18 sites had nesting but most (12) had nesting only once and none for all the years.  Adult count in 2003 (mostly non-breeding) was also the lowest since surveys began except for in 1999 when only 20 sites were surveyed.

column32: Leukering, Tony; Beason, Jason; Levad, Rich. 2004. Monitoring Colorado's birds: the 2003 field season report. In cooperation with Rocky Mountain Bird Observatory
column35: Per authors, active nest count = # nests detected + 0.5*(juveniles detected) (Table 14 and Table 20).  The Clark's grebe adults counted in 2003 are mostly non-breeding at Arkansas Valley reservoirs.  Lower numbers for 2003 are due to the lack of surveying at other reservoirs in CO.   Nesting sites in CO known to have been occupied in the last 3 years were censussed, except for Empire Reservoir due to access issues.  21 of 35 historical and potential Clark's grebe nesting sites were surveyed and 2 had confirmed breeding in 2003.  1999 survey data was omitted due to incomplete counts.  In 2002 and 2003, most of the large reservoirs of Arkansas Valley were not surveyed though they harbor a large proportion of non-breeding Clark's grebes.  Nesting was limited due to low water levels that reduced nesting opportunities.

column35: Table 2 - Results of the MCB survey of 448 water bodies in 46 counties, summer 2001 and Table 3 - Summary of MCB special monitoring projects, summer 2001 state different sets of numbers for sites surveyed, adults, and juveniles.  I entered Table 3 which was summarized in the Discussion although additional numbers of non-breeding adults are mentioned as part of an extensive lake survey (313 non-breeding Western grebes at 42 sites and 207 Aechmophorus sp. at 9 sites).  Those extra numbers do not appear in either tables so I did not enter them.  May request specific lake numbers from Ken Giesen of Colorado Division of Wildlife for more detail.  53 of 61 historical and potential Western grebe nesting sites in Colorado were surveyed.  Lakes that were not visited were of low priority with small numbers of nests on record and no recent nesting.  Six sites had confirmed breeding which was one less than in 2000.  The 666 adults counted were mostly non-breeding and was 300 lower than in 2000.  No specific lakes mentioned.

I entered Table 2 which was summarized in the Discussion.  I did not include Table 5 of the early-winter waterbird count.  May request specific lake numbers from Ken Giesen of Colorado Division of Wildlife for more detail.  44 of 59 historical and potential Western grebe nesting sites in Colorado were surveyed.  Lakes that were not visited were of low priority with small numbers of nests on record and no recent nesting.  Three sites had confirmed breeding due to low water levels.  The 1140 adults counted were mostly non-breeding and was about 400 more than in 2001.  No specific lakes mentioned.

column32: Leukering, T., and R. Levad. 2003. Monitoring Colorado’s Birds: The 2002 Field Season Report. Rocky Mountain Bird Observatory unpubl report. 32 pp.
column35: Table 2 - Results of MCB colonial waterbird counts, summer 2002 and Table 4 - Results of the MCB survey of water bodies, summer 2002, state different sets of numbers for sites surveyed, adults, and juveniles. May request specific lake numbers from Ken Giesen of Colorado Division of Wildlife for more detail.  24 of 36 historical and potential Clark's grebe nesting sites in Colorado were surveyed.  Lakes that were not visited were of low priority with small numbers of nests on record and no recent nesting.  The 90adults counted were mostly non-breeding and at 10 sites.  The 11 juveniles were at three sites.  Arkansas River Valley sites that had many non-breeding adults were not surveyed.  An additional 106 non-breeding Clark's grebe adults at 18 sites were counted on an extensive lakes survey.  I did not include these and they were not stated in any other tables of this report.  No specific lakes mentioned in the narrative.

I kept it as 90 according to Trost. The July 1, 1993 American Falls Reservoir (Rainbow Beach/Seagull Bay) survey is also included in G. Ivey's ID Waterbird Atlas spreadsheet for his work with Region 1 - Non Game.  In Ivey's spreadsheet, the median number for range of nests is reported as 35 and estimated # of breeding birds at 70 (conversion factor of nests by 2).  Also, the July 1, 1993 American Falls Reservoir (Snake River) survey is also included in G. Ivey's ID Waterbird Atlas spreadsheet for his work with Region 1 - Non Game.  In Ivey's spreadsheet, the median number for range of nests is reported as 100 and estimated # of breeding birds at 200 (conversion factor of nests by 2). As well, the July 25, 1993 American Falls Reservoir (near silo at dam) survey is also included in G. Ivey's ID Waterbird Atlas spreadsheet for his work with Region 1 - Non Game.  In Ivey's spreadsheet, the median number for range of nests is reported as 9 and estimated # of breeding birds at 18 (conversion factor of nests by 2). These various areas of American Falls are combined in this entry for Trost.

column35: Source is this study. The survey dates with Clark's observed (June 8, June 17, July 1, July 19) are proportioned (12.5%, 6%, 7%, 3% respectively) out of the total with Western's.  August 19 doesn't have a proportion but should be 3/74 = 4%. Included the Seagull Bay survey on July 1 which is another part of American Falls Reservoir, proportion Clark's is 7% or 2 out of 28 which is not a match for total on the Western's table.  3 chicks out of all of American Falls Reservoir. Cavitt historical data converts the 10 nests counted on June 8 by a factor of 2 for 20 additional breeding birds.  I didn't include that.  Also, states July 2 as 7 breeding birds instead of 6 as stated in Trost.  I left it as 6 (from Trost). Cavitt also states unknown survey type and estimate, not direct count, for this survey.  I'm assuming ground survey. The June 8, 1993 American Falls Reservoir (McTucker are) survey is also included in G. Ivey's ID Waterbird Atlas spreadsheet for his work with Region 1 - Non Game.  In Ivey's spreadsheet, the median number for range of nests is reported as 15 and estimated # of breeding birds at 30 (conversion factor of nests by 2). Also, the July 1, 1993 American Falls Reservoir (Rainbow Beach/Seagull Bay) survey is also included in G. Ivey's ID Waterbird Atlas spreadsheet for his work with Region 1 - Non Game.  In Ivey's spreadsheet, the median number for range of nests is reported as 2 and estimated # of breeding birds at 4 (conversion factor of nests by 2).

column33: Trost, C. H. n.d. Status and distribution of colonial nesting waterbirds in Idaho, 1985. 110.
column35: Source is this study.  This report's method was to send questionnaires to all refuge managers in Idaho and Trost's visit to all known colonies in May and June of 1984, counting nests from ground. Low # of range is total #s of nests seen. Higher # is either total birds or nests seen. Western Grebes were counted on open water from ground.  During incubation period, total # of birds seen on water assumes that one is on a nest, thus # of birds seen equals # of nests. After chicks hatched, both adults assumed to be in colony, thus divide in half # of adult birds seen for another nest estimate.

column35: Cascade Reservoir supports the largest Western and Clark's grebe breeding population in the state.  Water is very shallow around the perimeter.  For the last 8 years of annual adult surveys, the average number of adults is approximately 3000.  Includes University of Idaho Grebe Research Project data and some personal communication on 2022 (zero chicks counted by Betsy Wagner though our technicians may have seen some).  Only have # nest count data from 2003, 2004, 2017 to 2019 at this time. 2020, 2021, and 2022 nest count data is pending.

column33: Stanley, W. 1993. Western Grebe Survey - 1993 Memorandum. Document on file, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Deer Flat National Wildlife Refuge, Nampa ID.
column35: Pair and nesting surveys between 6 July and 27 July, 1993 but doesn't say how many. Three pair surveys by boat done week of 6 July. Mentions that pair count was stopped due to "several hundred pairs present" at Upper Pool so I interpreted this as >200 pairs and estimated this as maximum >400 individual adults. On 28 July, colony was characterized, nests counted. No exact number of surveys given so I estimated this as >4 surveys done (adult, nest, and brood surveys total).

column33: Waterbird Recreation Interaction Study. 2012. Report on file U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Deer Flat National Wildlife Refuge, Nampa ID.
column35: Report on boat interaction survey with grebes on a high use day (4 July) and low use day (10 July) in 2012.  This survey is not a grebe count and is included here because of boat disturbance theorized as a threat to grebe nesting and grebe broods at Lake Lowell.

column33: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Biological Opinion for Bureau of Reclamation Operations and Maintenance in the Snake River Basin above Brownlee Reservoir. 2005. 342.
column35:
No survey, just mercury analysis of eggs as potential threat. In 2003, Western/Clark's eggs collected for analysis. At Lake Lowell, mean mercury concentrations in eggs were below levels causing population-level effects but individual eggs exceeded thresholds for effect
(C. Thomas and S. Burch, in litt., 2005).

column32: Cavitt, J. F., S. L. Jones, N. M. Wilson, J. S Dieni, T. S. Zimmerman, R. H. Doster, and W. H. Howe. 2014. Atlas of breeding colonial waterbirds in the interior western United States. Research Report, U.S. Department of the Interior, Fish and Wildlife Service, Denver, Colorado.
column35: Narrows. Direct count of pairs to determine estimated # of breeding birds.  Conducted as part of Western Colonial Waterbird Survey (WCWS), a breeding survey of 18 species from May to July 2009 to 2011, resulting in this Atlas.

column33: Mohler, J. A. 2013. Grebe survey protocol. Document on file, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Deer Flat National Wildlife Refuge, Nampa ID.
column35: Protocol states that fluctuating water levels is a limiting factor to nesting, of which the USFWS has no control over.

column33: Mohler, J. A. 2015. 2015 Grebe surveys and annual report. Document on file, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Deer Flat National Wildlife Refuge, Nampa ID.
column35: Main takeaway from this report is the stated threat of low water levels.  Three pre-nesting surveys with no count #s conducted from 12 June to 3 July.  Four surveys of colony from 13 June to 5 September.  Only 20 nests marked but probably more due to difficulty of access. Three brood counts from 7 August to 19 September.  The data table for brood count has typo saying 2013.  I entered only 7 August data because other two dates beyond breeding season.  This data will be covered in historical summary of Lake Lowell so the main inclusion of this report is for the threat.

column32: USFWS and U of I unpublished data.  "2010-2021_Grebe_Summary_Historical_Data_DeerFlatNWR"
column35: Data compiled from Grebe Data 2010 through 2015 Excel spreadsheets from the FWS shared drive at Deer Flat NWR (DFNWR), obtained by Deo Lachman in 2019.  Other years’ data was compiled by Mark Lupher, volunteer at DFNWR in 2019. The 2019 to 2021 data was added on by Anne Yen in 2021.  Each year in the 12 year survey varies in terms of # surveys and dates of surveys for that year.  2019 to 2021 included drone use which detected higher number of nests but does not necessarily represent increased nesting than other years.  Nest detection in smartweed is very difficult by boat so nests numbers in other years could be comparably as high as 2019 and 2021 but not found.

column32: Owens, Eddie, email 2022, personal communications.
column35: There were no regular weekly surveys of Lake Lowell in 2022.  Eddie Owens, Refuge Manager, was able to survey twice from boat and observed courting, but no nesting nor chicks.  He observed that water was very low and smartweed was at 25% of usual levels.  He also walked the smartweed in late July 2022 because water was low and saw what looked like remnants of possibly old nests or stranded nests and sent me photos.  I thought they looked like old nests or other waterbird nests but not fresh grebe nests.

I noted the Clark's proportions given for June 22 and August 20 in the Clark's entry for Minidoka NWR (next line). For Cavitt, the 60 nests are doubled for an estimate of # breeding birds and actual bird count as 103.  It is 101 in Trost so I used that. The August 20, 1993 survey is also included in G. Ivey's ID Waterbird Atlas spreadsheet for his work with Region 1 - Non Game.  In Ivey's spreadsheet, the median number for range of nests is reported as 80 and estimated # of breeding birds at 160 (conversion factor of nests by 2).

The August 20 total count # and proportion of Clark's (37%) matches up with Western's count #. Cavitt doubles nest # of 35 to estimate # of breeding birds and says actual bird count is 50. column35: Swan Lake in Bannock County is considered "natural lake with stable water levels" despite 1.25 foot drop over study period.  No info on frequency of visits during study period. Water level drop isloates nests so that grebes couldn't reach them and possibly when vegetation the eggs are on dries out, incubation stops. Nest success of these 7 nests were 33.5%, hatching success 22.2% and the stated threats given percentages too.

column35: General description of threats relevant to most colonies in ID for Western and Clark's combined. Estimates about 4000 Westerns and 472 Clark's breeding in ID. More than half the Western grebes in the state's population breed in Cascade Reservoir.

column32: Cavitt, J. F., S. L. Jones, N. M. Wilson, J. S Dieni, T. S. Zimmerman, R. H. Doster, and W. H. Howe. 2014. Atlas of breeding colonial waterbirds in the interior western United States. Research Report, U.S. Department of the Interior, Fish and Wildlife Service, Denver, Colorado.
column35: Conducted as part of Western Colonial Waterbird Survey (WCWS), a breeding survey of 18 species from May to July 2009 to 2011, resulting in this Atlas.  State data, presented in Table 6, reflects maximum value across all surveys and years of WCWS for colonies visited more than once.  Nest counts were used to estimate breeding adult counts when possible as direct adult counts may include non-breeders.

column33: Burger, J., and B. Eichhorst. 2005. Heavy metals and selenium in grebe eggs from Agassiz National Wildlife Refuge in northern Minnesota. Environmental Monitoring and Assessment 107:285–295.
column35: Not a survey.  To test for heavy metal contaminants, eggs were collected from 4 species of grebes, including Western grebes.  Only 2 Western grebe eggs were collected so sample size was too small for statistics.  No other details provided but this is evidence of breeding at this site.

column33: Burger, J., and B. Eichhorst. 2007. Heavy Metals and Selenium in Grebe Feathers from Agassiz National Wildlife Refuge in Northern Minnesota. Archives of Environmental Contamination and Toxicology 53:442–449.
column35: Not a survey.  To test for heavy metal contaminants, feathers were collected from 4 species of grebes, including Western grebes.  Feathers of 5 young Western grebes were collected for contaminant testing.  Sample size was too small for statistical analysis but contaminant levels were reported because that information is lacking for Western grebes.  Pied-billed and Western grebes tested for the highest levels of lead in this study.  No other details provided but this is evidence of breeding at this site.

column32: Allen, Nuechterlein, and Buitron. 2008a. Bulrush mediation effects on wave action: implications for over-water nesting birds. 31(3): 411-416. Published by The Waterbird Society.
column35: No surveys conducted.  Artificial nest colony was established and wave action and reach was measured through bulrush stands of various densities.  Western grebes at this lake nested in dense bulrush stands with open pools and channels.  Clumps of bulrush with variable stem densities compose older bulrush stands that provide both protection from waves and water access for nesting grebes.

column32: Allen, Nuechterlein, and Buitron. 2008b. Weathering the Storm: How wind and waves impact Western grebe nest placement and sucess. 31(3): 402-410. Published by The Waterbird Society.
column35: Approximately 162 pairs, unpaired adults were not counted, maximum adults entered as 162 X 2 for 2005.  For 2006, entered estimated 242 adults from multiplying 121 nests by 2.  Total nests were not reported for 2006 so entered the 121 nests marked on 18 June 2006.  2006 was a year with greater storm activity than 2005 and had 48% nest success compared to 66% nest success in 2005.  Nests were also more successful when placed where there was more wave attenuating vegetation between the nest and the colony edge exposed to waves.  Wave action was responsible for most nest failure during this study.  Predation risk was rare and water level remained mostly constant.

column32: Allen, Nuechterlein, and Buitron. 2007. Resident nongame waterbird use following biomanipulation of a shallow lake. 71(4): 1158-1162. Published by The Journal of Wildlife Management.
column35: Since late 1960s, western grebes regularly nested in colonies of 6 to 177 nests on Lake Christina (Minnesota Department of Natural Resources, Natural Heritage Program, unpublished data).  The lake was treated with Rotenone in late 2003, to remove the fish community though many picsivorous birds are resident there.  Thus, fish density was low in 2004 but recovered in 2005.  The Western grebes staging at Lake Christina in May 2004 declined by >50% in early June while counts increased on Pelican Lake to >100 in June and July.  This contrasts with 2005 where grebe numbers were higher at Lake Christina than at Pelican Lake.  One Clark's grebe observed feeding a chick in 2005, noted as one chick in this entry though there was not a brood survey.  There were 63% of 315 nests hatching >=1 egg in 2005, however.  Minimum total population estimate is 215 pairs (430 individuals) but I entered the survey number counted from Table 1.  This study documents the abandonment of a lake after biomanipulation of the fish community and the subsequent recolonization.

The 1980 report summarizes colony status for 5 colonies but does not name them so is entered here as a statewide entry with no breeding lakes named.  There were 5 new breeding lakes reported for 1978.  In 1978, greater water abundance is thought to be the cause of higher Western grebe numbers than at any other time recorded in recent history, therefore low water levels was entered as a threat here.  Twelve sites had approximately 600 pairs, bringing the statewide total to greater or equal to 800 pairs.  In 1977, there were 20 recorded breeding lakes.  In 1978, there were 21 recorded breeding lakes with one inactive.  In 1980, there were 24 recorded breeding lakes with two inactive.  In 1980, five colonies were surveyed but does not state which ones.  Of these five, one was abandoned and there was a decrease in the numbers of breeding birds.  Declines were of 61%, 70%, and 97% in three colonies with an increase at one colony.  No other details provided nor names of grebe lakes.  These efforts were summarized in a 1982 paper cited here.

column32: Guertin, David S., and Lee A. Pfannmuller. 1985. “Colonial Waterbirds in Minnesota: An Update of their Distribution and Abundance.” Loon 57: 67–78.
column35: This report updates the MNDNR Minnesota Colonial Waterbird Nesting Inventory for 1981 to 1983.  As of 1983, there were 29 Western grebe colonies mostly in the western half of the state considered active during any of the report years.  Twenty-five of these colonies have 50 or fewer nests.  There are two colonies that are composed of 51 to 100 nests, one colony composed of 101 to 200 nests, and one colony composed of 201 to 300 nests (Lake Osakis in 1981).  Four colonies have unknown status.  Eight colonies were conisdered inactive.

column32: Soulliere, G. J., M. A. Al-Saffar, R. L. Pierce, M. J. Monfils, L. R. Wires, B. W. Loges, B. T. Shirkey, N. S. Miller, R. D. Schultheis, F. A. Nelson, A. M. Sidie-Slettedahl, C. M. Tonra, and D. J. Holm. 2018. Upper Mississippi River and Great Lakes Region Joint Venture Waterbird Habitat Conservation Strategy – 2018 Revision. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Bloomington, Minnesota, USA.
column35:
Not a survey but a strategic plan.  Inclusion here for information, Western grebe inclusion is minor.  "The JV region encompasses all or portions of Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, Ohio, and Wisconsin."  From species profile: "The Western Grebe is also a sporadic breeder in the JV region occurring in very low numbers. Except for the western part of BCR 12, there are no historical records for breeding and the species is believed to be a recent arrival in most of the region. Breeding records occur in either sewage ponds or natural shallow wetlands. Species’ presence may be in response to occasional drought conditions farther west in the Dakotas and Nebraska. Small increases in BCRs 22 and 23 in Minnesota are likely attributable to MN DNR’s shallow lake restoration program (e. g., Geneva Lake).
BCR 12 – 4 (MN–4, WI–0, MI–0)
BCR 22 – 12 (KS–0, NE–2, MO–0, IA–0, MN–10, WI–0, IL–0, IN–0, OH–0)
BCR 23 – 8 (IA–0, MN–6, WI–2, IL–0, IN–0, MI–0, OH–0)
Total JV region population estimate: 24 pairs."

column32: Smucker, Kristina. 2020. 12-Year Summary of Waterbird Surveys at Freezout Lake WMA 2009-2020. Montana Fish, Wildlife, and Parks.
column35: Part of the Western Colonial Waterbird Monitoring and Inventory (WCWS), this 2020 report is part of a 12-year study but only the average is given that includes previous years.  There is no data for other individual years included.  A 10-year average of nest numbers is 34 (combined Western and Clark's grebes).  More than 30% of Montana's breeding Western and Clark's grebes nest at Freezout Lake WMA.  This lake has numerous ponds and the main lake where grebes can colonize different locations annually.  Water levels were near or at capacity in 2020.  Years of low water levels in certain ponds had no nesting though that is not always a consistent indicator of nest numbers or productivity.  This is only one of two (Ninepipes is the other) documented sites where Clark's grebes have nested in Montana.  Western grebes are more common in the state with 19 sties of documented nesting though this study found nesting colonies in only 5 sites.  Colony sizes annually ranged from 5 to 77 nests though this range does not specify if this is an annual total or within amongst colonies in a year.

The 2014 data is captured in this entry, just adding that Clark's grebe colonies in Montana are small, usually 5 to 10 pairs.  There were 0 Clark's nests at Freezout Lake in 2014.  In 2009, the colony at Freezout Lake likley included both Western and Clark's grebes but were mostly Western grebes.  In 2014, Western grebe nesting was at 3 sites for a total of 99 but only 2 sites were included in Table 1 (which was what was entered). Martin (2023) states that water levels rose in the last 20 years and many lakes had a lack of grebes in the 80s and early 90s.

column32: Igl, L. 2023. Pers. comm.
column35: Larry Igl confirms that Western grebe (or Western and Clark's grebe) colonies were at this lake in the past.  He updated the years active as one or more years within the past 5 years via eBird as having Western grebes during the breeding season.  Therefore to generate his original list of ND lakes and then update the years most recently surveyed/observed might include multiple years.  He also thinks there are probably more ND lakes than is listed here that support grebe colonies.

column35: Survey methods are generalized across the different grebe breeding lakes because they were not specified per lake but an aerial survey was initially conducted. Entered is the grebe breeding pair total per breeding lake X2 for an estimation of adults numbers.  Average colony size for Sargent County is entered but no nest numbers per breeding lake is reported.

column32: https://www.allaboutbirds.org/news/birding-escapes-des-lacs-national-wildlife-refuge-north-dakota/
column35: Anecdotal, no literature documentation that I can find, just mentioned on the Cornell Lab's All About Birds website profile on Des Lacs NWR that this is where one can see five grebe species nesting, including Western.  This fun fact is then repeated on other websites.

column32: Stewart, R. E. (1975). Breeding birds of North Dakota. Tri-College Center for Environmental Studies.
column35: These are the only numbers reported as one of the larger colonies on record in the state.  A range of 1 to 3 chicks is estimated for the 50 broods in 1960 (H. L. Bradley).  For 1965, 130 chicks observed (H. L. Bradley) but no adult numbers.  Adults estimated here as 43 to 130 pairs (assuming 1 to 3 chicks per pair) and multiplying by 2 for 86 to 260 adults.

column32: Abbott, Gerard A., 1902. A Grebe Colony. Bird-lore 3-4, 1901-1902, page 86-87.
column35: Observation of the largest colony in the Devil's Lake region, described as 1500 birds, 75% of which are Western grebes, the other 500 as Eared grebes and some Pied grebes.  Entered as range of 1000 to 1125 adult Western grebes with evidence of nesting, though no nest numbers.  Dexcription of nest parisitism by Eared grebes and carcasses of both species found with wounds, assuming through fighting between the two species though unknown exactly how.

column32: Stewart, R. E. (1975). Breeding birds of North Dakota. Tri-College Center for Environmental Studies.

column35: Larry Igl confirms that Western grebe (or Western and Clark's grebe) colonies were at this lake in the past.  Larry Igl confirms that Western grebe (or Western and Clark's grebe) colonies were at this lake in the past.  He updated the years active as one or more years within the past 5 years via eBird as having Western grebes during the breeding season.  Therefore to generate his original list of ND lakes and then update the years most recently surveyed/observed might include multiple years.  He also thinks there are probably more ND lakes than is listed here that support grebe colonies.   This Willow Lake is in Rolette County.

column32: Drilling. N. E. 2015. North Dakota Colonial and Semi-colonial Waterbird Inventory, 2014-2015. Final Report. Tech. Rpt. SC-NDCWB02. Bird Conservancy of the Rockies, Brighton, CO, USA. 57 pp.
column35: Survey methods are generalized across the different grebe breeding lakes because they were not specified per lake but an aerial survey was initially conducted.  Survey was at least once in 2014 or 2015 with no further detail on each lake.  Grebe breeding pair total for ND was multiplied by 2 to estimate total adult number for ND and is considered a minimum.  There were 75 Western grebe colonies documented in ND for this inventory.  Colonies under 25 nests were not included in this inventory so actual pair and nest numbers may be higher for ND.  70% of grebe nests were in marsh vegetation with the rest in open water.  Three sites (unnamed) had nests built along busy roads with no sign of negative effects but observers were only on site for a limited time and longer-term effects are possible.  Clark's grebes were observed at some sites but there was no evidence of them breeding.  Threats were summarized generally with no specified breeding lake nor referred species named per threat but there was one documented instance of humans intentionally killing grebes.

column32: Brown, C. R., M.B. Brown, P.A. Johnsgard, J. Kren, and W.C. Scharf. 1996. Transactions of the Nebraska Academy of Sciences and Affiliated Societies. 79. https://digitalcommons.unl.edu/tnas/79
column35: Lake McConaughy is the largest lake in Nebraska with Lakes Ogallala and Keystone below the Kingsley Dam.  Observations of brrods in Keystone Lake in 1993 by (Rosche).  20 to 25 adults breeding in Lake McConaughy is just an estimate and total may be larger.  Otherwise, large numbers of adults observed over the summer.  Clark's grebe considered an occasional breeder with a brood observed in  1994, no other details.  One found dead in 1986 at Keystone Lake.  Host to several thousand in spring and fall migration.

column32: Parmelee, D. F., & Parmelee, J. M. 1997. Western Grebe and Clark’s Grebe: Habitat Necessity versus Phenology. Colonial Waterbirds, 20(1), 95–97. https://doi.org/10.2307/1521768
column35: Drastic drop in water levels at Lake Mead in 1995 altered the marsh habitat grebes used for nesting.  The grebes changed the start of courtship to when water returned along with their marsh habitat and laid eggs in mid-August during high temperatures.  They also laid eggs in mid-December when temperatures were the coldest.  Though December is far outside the typical breeding months, there is description of 400 pairs in the colony so the 800 estimated individuals are included here.  Frequent human disturbance of this colony but no apparent reduction in breeding activity per authors; 1993 sighting of 30 chicks does not specify origin colony, could be total of the three colonies.

column33: Jackson, A., D. C. Evers, C. A. Eagles-Smith, J. T. Ackerman, J. J. Willacker, J. E. Elliott, J. M. Lepak, S. S. Vander Pol, and C. E. Bryan. 2016. Mercury risk to avian piscivores across western United States and Canada. Science of The Total Environment 568:685–696.
column35: Modeling showed that prey fish THg concentrations were very highly correlated to grebe blood THg concentrations in sampled tissues of piscivores. Great Basin of OR and Nevada were areas of concern from the modelling

column32: Kosciuch K., D. Riser-Espinoza, M. Gerringer, W. Erickson. 2020. A summary of bird mortality at photovoltaic utility scale solar facilities in the Southwestern U.S.. PLoS ONE 15(4): e0232034. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0232034
column35: Bird mortality reports from 10 photovoltaic solar facilities across 13 site years in California and Nevada were synthesized.  Water obligate birds like grebes made up 90% of the mortalities, leading some researches to believe that these kinds of birds mistook solar panels as water.  Other "large downing events" the authors cite, involve Western grebes during poor weather or with wet parking lots.  I did not add this as a threat listed here because this is more during migration but included it here as a matter of interest.

column32: Ivey, G.. Grebe nest count and trend at Malheur 1980-1998 - email and excerpt of report.  The numbers in the email don't match up to the graph in the report excerpt though.
column35: Significant declining trend, highest nest estimates in the early 1980s at a time of young aged fish due to carp control (with rotenone) and high water levels that increased fish habitat.  Number of nests declined by 1985 due to limited nesting habitat and fish too large.  In 1993, water levels increased post-drought and nesting increased, along with more small fish and more nesting substrate.  Numbers avg 2.5 times higher in wet years than dry years, corresponding to increase in wetland habitats and annual precip but not with water levels or surface area.

column32: Spencer, K. 2003. Western Grebe. Pp. 34-37 in Birds of Oregon: A General Reference. D.B.Marshall, M.G. Hunter, and A.L. Contreras, Eds. Oregon State University Press, Corvallis, OR. (cites Littlefield 1990a) for nest # in 1983.
column35: Didn't breed in highwater years of 1989 and 1990 because aquatic vegetation was inundated.  However peak #s in 1984 due to flooding which supported abundant young fish to feed on.  At Malheur NWR (not specified where), low water years is when carp control is carried out and is when carp is too large for grebes.  Also at Malheur NWR (not specified where), in 1980-1998, populations averaged 2.5 higher in wet years versus dry years.  At Malheur NWR (not specified where), in late 1950s, wave action destroyed Western grebe nest colonies.

column35: Observer estimated number of breeding birds (and nests) was obtained by counting pairs on transects and X4.12 for area coverage and X2 for visibility index.  Actual counts in 1980 (268 and 134), 1981 (794), and 1982 (424) were much lower but this database reports adjusted and estimated numbers for most of its surveys so for consistency within the site, entering the estimated number of birds.  Counts estimated for Western grebes but most likely included Clark's grebes.  Survey type is possibly aerial but not certain.

column35: Goose Bay is part of Williamson River Delta Preserve, Upper Klamath Lake. From 2009 to 2011, Klamath Bird Observatory surveyed waterbirds, as part of USFWS' Western Colonial Waterbird Survey.  In 2010 and 2011, included colonial nesting waterbirds like Western and Clark's grebes. Empty nests and chicks on adult chicks confirms grebe breeding in 2010 survey.  In 2011, breeding confirmed by incubating Western and Clark's grebes.  The Nature Conservancy owns and restored 5,550 acres of wetlands (see TNC's Bird Life at the Williamson River Delta 2010 Comprehensive Report by Melody Warner).

column32: Ratti, J. T. 1985. A test of water depth niche partitioning by Western Grebe color morphs. Auk 102:635-637.
column35: Totals calculated from Table 1.  This paper tested water-depth and distance from shore niches between light and dark phased Western grebes.  Light-phased Western grebes fed farther from the shore than dark-phased Western grebes but were not found feed at greater water depths.

column32: Vradenburg, J. 2021. Pers comm.
column35: Not a survey but just an entry of threats conveyed by John Vradenburg, Supervisory Wildlife Biologist for the Kilamath Basin National Wildlife Refuge Complex.  He responded to our outreach to him that Upper Klamath Lake was impacted by different challenges from the other sites of the Klamath Basin NWR Complex.  There was a lack of recruitment of juvenile endangered suckers which alters water management.  Water was held higher and at a more stable level than previous years.  However, this negatively impacts submergent and emergent vegetation and reduces nesting habitat.  Remaining stands of emergent vegetation become dislodged and floats away.  Unfortunately, the focus on fish does not consider wetlands, waterbirds, nor the ecological drivers of species declines.  He expressed the need to address these issues at the forefront before additional species are listed, prompting recovery actions.

column32: Shuford, W.D., D.L. Thomson, D.M. Mauser, and J. Beckstrand. 2004. Abundance, Distribution, and Phenology of Nongame Waterbirds in the Klamath Basin of Oregon and California. PRBO Conservation Science. Final Report to Klamath Basin National Wildlife Refuge Complex.
column35: Surveyed for 3 periods: spring migration, mid-breeding, and fall migration in 2003. Numbers here are just during mid-breeding season (June 12 to 23).  Data is grouped by area and not broken down by lake/reservoir so some listed here may not be a breeding lake. Upper Klamath Lake area includes lakes 1 through 10, Agency Lake Ranch, Running Y wetlands, Williamson River Delta Preserve, and Wood River Wetland. Upper Klamath Lake, in general, is the most important site for Western and Clark's grebes in the Klamath Basin, supporting >60% of these grebes for all seasons. An estimate of nests #s was conducted via ground (at a poor vantage point) on 16 June, 2003 of 940 nests and via air on 17 June, 2003 of 1041 nests of a large colony in Shoalwater Bay of the lake. On 17 June, 2003, an aerial survey estimated 100 nests at Hank's Marsh at the lake. This entry represents the combined nest #s of 1041 nests at Shoalwater Bay and 100 nests at Hank's Marsh for a total of 1141 nests.

column35: Surveyed for 3 periods: spring migration, mid-breeding, and fall migration in 2004.  Data is grouped by area and not broken down by lake/reservoir so some listed here may not be a breeding lake.  Numbers here are just during mid-breeding season (June 9 to 16).  Upper Klamath Lake area includes lakes 1 through 11, Agency Lake Ranch, Running Y wetlands, Williamson River Delta Preserve, and Wood River Wetland.  Upper Klamath Lake, in general, is the most important site for Western and Clark's grebes in the Klamath Basin, supporting 62-75% of these grebes for both years across all seasons.  Upper Klamath Lake area had 70-80% of all Western Grebes surveyed across both years.  An estimate of nests #s was in the narrative and includes Shoalwater Bay, Hank's Marsh, and Agency Lake (no numbers).  Broods were estimated at a range of 1 to 3 chicks per brood.

column35: This is the final report of the 2nd South Dakota Breeding Bird Atlas (SDBB2).  Western grebes were rarely observed for the first atlas, during which was a dry period.  For surveys conducted from 2005 to 2007 and 2012, conditions were wetter and there were between 40 to 45 colonies annually (Drilling 2007, 2013).  Most colonies in this state are small (<50) though a colony in the southwest part of Marshall County (lake not named) had 250 broods (entered as a range of 1 to 3 chicks per brood).  Surveys from 2008 to 2012 for SDBB2 surveyed pre-selected 3 mile x 3 mile blocks.  May need to request these details.

column32: Drilling, N. E. 2007. South Dakota Statewide Colonial and Semi-colonial Waterbird Inventory with a Plan for Long-term Monitoring: Final Report. SDGFP Wildlife Division Report 2008-01A. RMBO Tech. Rep. M-Colony SD-04. Rocky Mountain Bird Observatory, Brighton, CO. 80 pp.
column35: This report does not state counts of grebes per site though such data was collected per site.  There were 45 colonies of Western grebes, three of which had >25% of the population.  Clark's grebes were observed but no evidence of nesting was detected.  This report gives totals per county.  Minimum and maximum of estimated adult #s are three-year cumulative total estimated from total breeding pairs.  Chick and nest count numbers not reported but surveys were conducted.  Threats discussed pertained to surveyed waterbird colonies in general with some pertaining to grebes specifically.  May request database access for more details on sites.

column32: Drilling. N. E. 2013. South Dakota 2012 Colonial Waterbird Survey. Tech. Rpt. SC-ColonySD-06. Rocky Mountain Bird Observatory, Brighton, CO, USA. 26 pp.
column35: This report does not state counts of grebes per site though such data was collected per site.  There were 44 colonies of Western grebes in 2012, compared to 45 in 2005-2007.  Of these 44 colonies, one had >25% of the population.  In 2012, there were 9 breeding pairs of Clark's grebes in six colonies compared to no evidence of breeding in 2005 to 2007.  The minimum estimated adult # is from the minimum three-year cumulative total (2005 - 2007) estimated from total breeding pairs.  Total estimated breeding adults is from total breeding pairs X2.  Chick and nest count numbers not reported but surveys were conducted.  Fluctuating water levels is stated as a factor where grebes in general build their colonies but does not name grebe species or particular sites.  Recommendations include future monitoring of all grebe colonies, not just major waterbird colonies, because grebes tend to nest in small or single-species colonies.  May request database access for more details on sites.

column35: Survey data of adult grebes between 11 June and 30 July in 1974 is about 690, which might be averaged across the dates because Figure 1 shows more.  Survey data of the same time range in 1973 is not given but I estimated it at approximately 560 adult grebes according to Figure 1.  Did not include August and September count (not stated) of higher adult numbers due to migration and inclusion of young.  There was a cumulative nest total of 386 for 1973 and 1974 together but states that in 1974, 202 nests were found.  Therefore, I subtracted 202 from 386 for 1973 nest count total.  Chick count for each year is only Class 2 (free-swimming chicks).

column33: Ratti, J. T. 1979. Reproductive separation and isolating mechanisms between sympatric dark- and light-phase Western grebes. The Auk 96:14.
column35: Western and Clark's grebes were considered dark and light phases during this study.  Proportion Clark's grebe to Western grebe is light phase to dark phase to intermittent (approximate).  Adult numbers estimated from pair counts per survey from Table 1.  Nest count is from all 10 colonies from Table 3 for both 1975 and 1976 combined total.   Chick numbers estimated brood counts for each year X 1 to 3 chick range (99% of broods were in this range # of chicks).

column30: every 3-4 days for nests, weekly for broods for summer
column32:
Lindvall, Mark L., 1976. Breeding Biology and Pesticide-PCB Contamination of Western Grebe at Bear River Migratory Bird Refuge. All Graduate Theses and Dissertations. 4394.
https://digitalcommons.usu.edu/etd/4394
column35: 1974 surveying methods were more comprehensive than in 1973 so numbers are higher probably because of that.  Researchers banded 19 Western grebe juveniles and 16 adults in 1973.  Largest reported summer population is here, according to surveys sent out to 5 areas of Utah where >100 Western grebes breed.  The minimum adult and chick counts of 1973 and 1974 are from Table 16 and Table 17 respectively, looking at June through late-August.  840 is reported as the peak adult count between 11 June and 30 July 1974 and 680 is the average of the weekly counts in that period.  I did not include late August and onward counts as the paper called that post-breeding.  Minimum and maximum chick numbers are estimated from Figure 3 starting from mid-June.  This study has separate totals for Class 2 (free swimming) chicks estimated two different ways that I did not enter here.  They are 124 and 158 Class 2 chicks in 1973 and 218 and 269 Class 2 chicks in 1974.  Lindvall calculated nest success using Class 2 chicks per adults.  54% of the total 386 nests were in emergent vegetation, 41% were in open water, and 5% were on dry land.  Table 2 (1973) and Table 3 (1974) provides nest characteristic and nest success data, including threats and their impacts.  Egg predation, nest abandonment, and water level drops are named as the most major threats.  A loss of 25% of total nests to abandonment, including one entire colony, is attributed to a decrease in water levels.  The abandoned colony was located in an area where water level is not managed.

column32: Ratti, J. T. 1985. A test of water depth niche partitioning by Western Grebe color morphs. Auk 102:635-637.
column35: Totals calculated from Table 1.  This paper tested water-depth and distance from shore niches between light and dark phased Western grebes.  Light-phased Western grebes fed farther from the shore than dark-phased Western grebes but were not found feed at greater water depths.

column32: Ramirez P., Jr. 2010. Bird mortality in oil field wastewater disposal facilities. Environmental management, 46(5), 820–826. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00267-010-9557-4
column35: Not a survey but a placeholder for a threat that might affect migrating grebes.  Commercial and centralized oilfield wastewater disposal facilities (COWDFs) utilize vast evaporation pools to capture wastewater produced by oil and natural gas wells.   Birds might mistake these for wetlands and could die if they land in these evaporation pools and are covered in oil.  For this study, 9 of 28 COWDFs in Wyoming were conducted to examine mortality of birds.  Grebes (Family Podicipedidae), incl;uding Western grebes, were amongst the most common bird carcass encountered (28% of total mortalities).  In Campbell County, grebes accounted for 86% of total mortalities.  Western grebes accounted for 6 of the total mortalities.

column32: Orabona, A.C., and K.A. Hubbard.  Wyoming Game and Fish Department Western grebe species account.  SWAP.  https://wgfd.wyo.gov/WGFD/media/content/PDF/Habitat/SWAP/Birds/Western-Grebe.pdf
column35: Not a survey but a species account that provides state breeding population estimates and information about threats to Western grebes in Wyoming.  Two ranges of breeding population estimates and corresponding year range of surveys are WGFD annual surveys from 1997 to 2010 and Wyoming BBS surveys annually 1987 to 2015.

column32: Orabona, A.C., and K.A. Hubbard.  Wyoming Game and Fish Department Western grebe species account.  SWAP.  https://wgfd.wyo.gov/WGFD/media/content/PDF/Habitat/SWAP/Birds/Western-Grebe.pdf
column35: Not a survey but a species account that provides state breeding population estimates and information about threats to Clark's grebes in Wyoming.  Clark's grebes are considered very rare in Wyoming with none recorded in most years of BBS surveys.  Three ranges of breeding population estimates and corresponding year range of surveys are WGFD annual surveys from 2002 to 2006, Wyoming BBS surveys annually 1987 to 2015, and Integrated Monitoring in Bird Conservation Regions (IMBCR) surveys between 2009 to 2015.

column32: Ivey, G.L., and C.P. Herziger. 2006. Intermountain West Waterbird Conservation Plan, Version 1.2. A plan associated with the Waterbird Conservation for the Americas Initiative. Published by U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Pacific Region, Portland, Oregon.
column35: Not a survey but a list of threats to the Intermountain West.

column33: Haig, S. M., S. P. Murphy, J. H. Matthews, I. Arismendi, and M. Safeeq. 2019. Climate-Altered Wetlands Challenge Waterbird Use and Migratory Connectivity in Arid Landscapes. Scientific Reports 9:4666.
column35: Not a survey but describes diminished use of Great Basin wetlands by waterbirds throughout the year due to climate change impacts on hydrology. Climate change impacts on these wetlands include reduced water availability, higher salinity, reduced snowpack, reduced streamflow, decrease in water quality, reduced lake size, warmer temperatures, drier/drough conditions, etc. Looking at trends in waterbird abundance via USGS BBS (1968-2015) and trends in temperature, precipitation and streamflow (1980-2015 for these), there is a negative relationship for Western and Clark's grebes with temperature (-0.54) and precipitation (-0.28) trends and a positive (0.10 for duration, 0.34 for magnitude) with streamflow trends.

column35: Findings show particularly high levels of mercury contamination in fish across the Great Basin in Nevada and Oregon; mercury levels in tissue and blood samples of Aechmophorus grebes mirror those found in appropriate fish species
